awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Advancing Supply Prepositioning for Emergency Preparedness by Social Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
Foreseen disasters, such as hurricanes, snowstorms and droughts, can be detected several days prior to their landfall. To ameliorate the consequences of these disasters, humanitarian and governmental agencies can utilize forecast information to conduct preparedness activities. However, one unresolved challenge is to obtain accurate estimation of spatial-temporal heterogeneous supply demand for supply prepositioning. To tackle this challenge, this research plans an approach which integrates data from social media and simulation to predict demand for humanitarian supplies. Resulting models and prototype tools are expected to contribute to support for improving communication with the public, for optimizing supply prepositioning strategies, and for facilitating decision-making to help prevent or ameliorate the impacts of extreme disasters. This research will also lead to new educational modules and software useful for teaching undergraduate and graduate students how to design, analyze and implement a humanitarian logistics system. 

This research will investigate the potential for integrating social media data and agent-based simulation to reduce uncertainty associated with the demand for post-disaster relief supplies. This project will develop a new social sensing approach based on the integration of social media analysis and agent-based simulation. Trustworthy information will be extracted from social media by a new spatio-temporal Bayesian method. Second, this project will build a new forecast-driven multi-commodity supply prepositioning model that incorporates Markovian and decision theoretic perspectives within a stochastic optimization framework. Third, the outcome of the supply prepositioning will be realized by social delivery, an emerging delivery scheme that leverages delivery power from both fleet and volunteers' vehicles. Different optimization decomposition techniques will be examined and developed to handle the large-scale nature of the considered problem. To test the validity of the approaches, a range of case studies will be conducted.

Project Outcomes Report for NSF Award 1663101 - ?Collaborative Research: Advancing Supply Prepositioning for Emergency Preparedness by Social Sensing and Social Delivery?

This research investigates the potential of using social media and agent-based simulation as an integrated tool to reduce demand uncertainty and enhance delivery efficiency for dynamic supply prepositioning in preparation for a foreseen disaster (e.g. hurricane, snowstorm, and drought).

The first step in our research is to use a social media mining and agent-based simulation integrated approach to capture social interactions and human purchase behavior towards an accurate estimation of spatial-temporal supply demand. The social media platform that this research is based off is Twitter, which was mainly selected for two reasons: (a) availability of Twitter data for past dates and regions, which enabled us to research prior disaster events; and (b) suitability of Twitter for broadcasting warnings and guidance on evacuation and search planning after a disaster event.

The second step in our research was to develop, test and use a forecast-driven dynamic model for prepositioning relief items, using updated supply demand and forecast advisories from government agencies.

Third, a social delivery approach was examined for supply prepositioning and repositioning, including both original fleet and volunteer cars. Even though disaster preparedness and response has received lots of attention, advanced tools like agent-based simulation and social delivery have not been applied widely; furthermore, the recognition of social media presence and supply prepositioning are at the nascent stage. This research fills this gap. In pursuit of this goal, decision theory and stochastic optimization approaches are primarily taken to determine the optimal prepositioning flow, while an integrated texting mining and agent-based simulation approach is used to sense relief supply demand. To test the validity of the proposed approaches, case studies with different characteristics are executed based on real data sets on past Hurricane events. 

Results of this research advance our operational ability to prepare disaster relief supplies under various scenarios; in consequence, the humanitarian logistics before a foreseen disaster is greatly enhanced. Collectively, this research offers an innovative supply prepositioning framework that models supply demand estimation, dynamic prepositioning, and social crowdsourced delivery. The proposed work has the following key intellectual contributions: First, this project developed a new social sensing approach based on the integration of social media analysis and agent-based simulation. Trustworthy information is extracted from social media by a new spatial-temporal Bayesian method. The extracted knowledge is utilized to predict human purchase behavior and supply demand in preparation for a disaster. Second, Markov models, decision theory and stochastic optimization are applied for the development of a forecast-driven multi-commodity supply preposition model. Third, the outcome of the supply prepositioning is realized by social delivery, an emerging delivery scheme that leverages delivery power from both fleet and volunteer cars. Different optimization decomposition techniques are examined and developed to handle the large-scale nature of the considered problem.

The models and tools developed through this collaborative effort will provide substantial support to disaster management officers by improving communication with the public via social media use, optimizing supply prepositioning strategies, and facilitating decision-making to help prevent or ameliorate the impacts of extreme disasters. This research provides the transportation and humanitarian logistics communities with novel modeling, algorithmic and simulation foundations of social sensing and social delivery for emergency preparedness. It has led to new educational modules and software useful for teaching advanced undergraduate and graduate students how to design, analyze and implement a humanitarian logistics system. It also has provided a basis for communication among policymakers, the general public and retailers. When implemented in practice, the results of this research will likely bring large economic impacts to not only government agencies, but also industry leaders in emergency supply preparation. Furthermore, this research has the potential to invoke similar research in studying data mining, simulation, location problems, and military logistics. The developed models and software was presented in the UB National Summer Transportation Institute and UA Summer Engineering Academy attracting top high school students, especially women and minority, to science and engineering. Furthermore, research findings has been disseminated via journal articles and conference presentations. Finally, several undergraduate, masters and doctoral students have been trained by the PIs as a result of this research.
